summary: This document is a chain of emails from July 2019 discussing a potential International Megan's Law (IML) violation by Jeffrey Epstein. It details unreported international travel by Epstein to Vienna, Austria and Morocco in March and April 2019, and is shared between law enforcement officials in the US Virgin Islands, the FBI, and the U.S. Marshals Service to support the argument that Epstein is a flight risk.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The subject of the investigation for potential International Megan's Law violations due to unreported travel to Vienna and Morocco while a registered sex offender.

persons.name: Senior Inspector
persons.context: The U.S. Marshals Service investigator who compiled the report on Epstein's unreported travel and sent it to the U.S. Attorney's Office.

connections.description: The Senior Inspector from the U.S. Marshals Service is investigating Epstein for potential International Megan's Law violations related to unreported travel.

events.title: Epstein signs IML travel notification form
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein signed the Virgin Islands sex offender registry 'Notification of Duty to Report Travel' form, acknowledging his obligation to report international travel.

events.title: Unreported travel to Vienna
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein traveled to Vienna, Austria with three female passengers, where they went for coffee. This travel was not reported as required by International Megan's Law.

events.title: Unreported travel to Morocco
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein traveled to Morocco. This travel was also not reported as required by International Megan's Law.

keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein was under active FBI investigation nationwide as of July 2019.
Epstein failed to report international travel to Vienna, Austria (March 22, 2019) and Morocco (April 25, 2019) as required by his sex offender registration under International Megan's Law.
Law enforcement officials believed this pattern of unreported travel demonstrated Epstein was a flight risk.
The investigation into the IML violation was ongoing and officials were concerned public disclosure could hamper their ability to confirm information.
The information was being shared between the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York (SDNY), the FBI, and the U.S. Marshals Service.
